hw.question:
Two people are trying to decide whether a die is fair. They roll it 100 times, with the results shown below. One person wants to make a z-test, the other wants to make a $\chi^2$-test. Who is right? Explain briefly. Then, calculate the $P$-value of the respective test. Is the die fair?
21 ⚀'s 15 ⚁'s 13 ⚂'s 17 ⚃'s 19 ⚄'s 15 ⚅'s
\begin{align} \text{Average of numbers rolled} \approx 3.43, SD \approx 1.76 \end{align}
Sample Correct Solution
A $\chi^2$-test should be conducted, because we are interested in how well the rolls match the box, not just the average. For example, if we rolled ⚂ half the time and ⚃ the other half, we would be suspicious even though the average is exactly 3.5 as expected. Thus, we need to see whether the frequency of every outcome is close to its expected frequency, which is $\frac{100}{6} \approx 16.67\%$. With a $\chi^2$-test, $\chi^2$=2.6 on 5 degrees of freedom, which corresponds to $P \approx 75\%$. This is a good fit, and the die is fair.
Grading Rubric
Please grade this question out of 6 points following these guidelines.
2 points for arguing that a $\chi^2$-test should be made, with appropriate justification.
1 point for calculating $\chi^2 = 2.5$.
1 point for using 5 degrees of freedom.
1 point for calculating $P \approx 75\%$ using the table.
1 point for concluding that the die is fair. (If the student calculated an incorrect $P$-value of less than 5%, award them the 1 point for concluding the die is not fair.)

question.p: The U.S. has bilateral extradition treaties with many countries. (A person charged with a crime in his home country may escape to the U.S.; if he is captured in the U.S., authorities in his home country may request that he be "extradited," that is, turned over for prosecution under their laws.) The Senate attached a special rider to the treaty governing extradition to Northern Ireland: fugitives cannot be returned if they will be discriminated against on the basis of religion. In a leading case, the defense tried to establish discrimination in Northern Ireland's criminal justice system.

One argument was based on 1991 acquittal rates for persons charged with terrorist offenses. According to a defense expert, these rates were significantly different for Protestants and Catholics. The data are shown below: 8 Protestants out of 15 were acquitted, compared to 27 Catholics out of 65.

The defense expert calculated $\chi^2 \approx 6.2$ with 1 degree of freedom, and concluded $P \approx 1\%$. He concluded that this was evidence of discrimination. In this problem, we will check his work.
First, fill in the table with expected counts.

question.p: Juniors in Redwood City high school are assigned to 2 math teachers at random. A simple random sample of 100 juniors was followed for 5 years. Out of 50 juniors in Mr. Smith’s class, 28% majored in a STEM field, 42% majored in a different field, and 30% did not go to a 4-year college. Out of 50 juniors in Mr. Chang’s class, 42% majored in a STEM field, 28% majored in a different field, and 30% did not go to a 4-year college. We believe the teachers had an influence on the students’ future path.
Perform a hypothesis test. Show your calculations, and please use the table in the book to calculate the $P$-value. Be sure to state the null hypothesis.

This question is based on this comic.

ol.li: Explain the main point of the comic. Do the findings give us strong reason to believe there is a link between green jelly beans and acne? If not, what error is being made.

The newspaper article at the bottom of the comic proclaims "Green jelly beans linked to acne! 95% confidence". What do confidence intervals have to do with the hypothesis test the investigators conducted for green jelly beans?

Suppose the original $P$-value for jelly beans (as a whole) and acne was 6%. Instead of conducting studies for different colors (or playing minecraft), the scientists reconducted the original study for all jelly beans, but with substantially more subjects. They found that eating jelly beans increases risk of acne by $0.05\%$. This difference was very significant, with a $P$-value of 0.1%. Do we now have cause to be concerned about eating jelly beans?

solution.p: The major issue with the comic is that we are testing multiple hypotheses without accounting for it. With 20 different jelly bean colors, even if none of the jelly beans had any effect on acne, we'd expect one false positive.

Confidence intervals and hypothesis tests are closely related. Rejecting the null hypothesis that green jelly beans have no effect at the 5% level is the same as saying that a 95% confidence interval for the effect size does not include zero. (See Lecture 25.)
As for the revised study, although the difference is statistically significant, a difference of 0.05% is practically unimportant.
Please grade this question out of 6 points following these guidelines:

ul.li: 2 points for pointing out that the original comic was testing multiple hypotheses (a.k.a. data snooping) without adjusting for it.
2 points for noting that rejecting the null hypothesis in this case means that a 95% confidence interval for the effect size would not include the null effect.
2 points for remarking on the difference between statistical and practical significance for the new study.
